definitions.definition: to rest your weight on your bottom with your back straight, for example on/in a chair

examples.text: She sat and stared at the letter in front of her.
May I sit here?
Don't just sit there—do something!
Just **sit still!**
He went and sat beside her.
the man who had sat next to me on the plane
She was sitting at her desk.
She always sits in that chair.
Four people sat around the table.
It’s too cold to **sit outside**.
The children were all **sitting quietly** and listening.
Make sure you are **sitting comfortably**, with your back straight and supported.
She came over to talk to us, leaving him **sitting alone**.
We asked the waiter for a bigger table so that we could all **sit together**.
He **just sits** there **watching** the television.
We sat talking for hours.
I **sat waiting** for the soloist to walk onto the stage.
Elmer was happily sitting in his high chair.
He sat bolt upright, hands folded in front of him.
He was sitting against the wall.
He would sit quietly and watch what was happening.
She sat demurely on the edge of her chair.
She sat under an apple tree.
She was sitting astride a horse.
The children sat cross-legged on the floor.
The manager sat behind his desk.
They sat opposite each other.
The kids sat around a campfire.
We sat at a table in the corner.
We sat in silence for a few moments.
We reached the hospital and were told to sit in the waiting room.
I can't just sit in front of the computer for hours.
He was sitting on the couch with a book when I got home.
She noticed the older man sitting across from her.

definitions.definition: to put somebody in a sitting position

examples.text: He lifted the child and sat her on the wall.
She sat him down in front of the fire with a hot drink.

definitions.definition: to be in a particular place

examples.text: A large bus was sitting outside.
The pot was sitting in a pool of water.
I have an exercise bike just sitting at home not being used.
The jacket sat beautifully on her shoulders *(= fitted well)*.
The box sat unopened on the shelf.

definitions.definition: to have an official position as something or as a member of something
definitions.sensetop: sit as somethingsit in/on somethingsit for something

examples.text: He was sitting as a temporary judge.
They both sat as MPs in the House of Commons.
She sat on a number of committees.
For years he sat for Henley *(= was the MP for that ).

definitions.definition: to meet in order to do official business

examples.text: Parliament sits for less than six months of the year.
Candidates will sit the examinations in June.
Most of the students sit at least 5 GCSEs.
He was about to sit for his entrance exam.

definitions.definition: to rest on a branch, etc. or to stay on a nest to keep the eggs warm
to sit on its bottom with its front legs straight

examples.text: Rover! Sit!

definitions.definition: to take care of babies or children for a short time while their parents are out
definitions.labels: (especially North American English)British and North American English

examples.text: Who's sitting for you?

definitions.definition: to be in a good situation, especially when others are not

examples.text: With profits at record levels, the company’s certainly sitting pretty this year.

definitions.definition: to feel so satisfied with what you have already achieved that you do not try to do any more
to admire somebody very much, especially a teacher or somebody that you try to learn from
to sit or stand with your back straight
to seem right, natural, suitable, etc. in a particular place or situation

examples.text: His views did not sit comfortably with the management line.

definitions.definition: to decide whether somebody’s behaviour is right or wrong, especially when you have no right to do this

examples.text: How dare you sit in judgement on me?

definitions.definition: to avoid becoming involved in deciding or influencing something

examples.text: He tends to sit on the fence at meetings.

definitions.definition: to do or say nothing to help somebody or deal with a difficult situation

examples.text: We can’t sit silently by and let them arrest him!

definitions.definition: to stay where you are rather than moving away or changing position

examples.text: We sat tight and waited to be rescued.

definitions.definition: to stay in the same situation, without changing your mind or taking any action

examples.text: Shareholders are being advised to sit tight until the crisis passes.

wordOrigin: Old English sittan, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch zitten, German sitzen, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin sedere and Greek hezesthai.
